Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, heart pounding. The production manager’s message flashed: “Main unit down. Sensor errors again. Need you ASAP.” I was already on my way, toolbox in hand, mind racing through possible causes—faulty wiring, misaligned sensors, maybe a software glitch. Every minute the line was down cost the company money, and everyone expected me to fix it, fast.

But today was also election day. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t skip it, no matter what. I joined the line at the polling station, my badge still clipped to my shirt. The line was slow, but steady. Suddenly, an official called out, “Voters A through M, please move to the new line!” My last name started with H. The new line was longer, but the official insisted. “Please follow instructions, sir.”

I hesitated, torn. If I stayed, I’d be late to the factory, letting down my team. If I left, I’d be ignoring the official’s directions, maybe even causing trouble at the polls. My phone buzzed again. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
